In Iraq, a lack of government support for the needy has prompted some citizens to take matters into their own hands.

NPR's Lourdes Garcia-Navarro has the story from the Iraqi capital.

Neda Alwan(ph) hesitantly peeks around the door.

A widow with five children, Neda suddenly smiles when she sees who's come to visit.

The visitor, Nadal Hussein, is well-known here.
She's lived in this neighborhood all her life.
In 2004, Nadal's husband was killed in a rocket attack.
Their three children were hideously burned - one lost his leg.
Instead of being consumed with grief, she decided to help others like herself.
In 2005, Nadal joined six friends from her neighborhood, Karradah, to aid the less fortunate.
(Through translator) Nobody helped me, so I decided to help others to make a small change in these bad circumstances that we live in.
My dream was to place a smile on the face of a widow or an orphan.
Nadal and her friends help about 400 families in the neighborhood.
Among them, Neda, the woman she's visiting, and her five children.

Neighbors have instead killed neighbors.
